awd_titl_txt: TWC: Large: Collaborative: Verifiable Hardware: Chips that Prove their Own Correctness
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses how semiconductor designers can verify the correctness of ICs that they source from possibly untrusted fabricators.  Existing solutions to this problem are either based on legal and contractual obligations, or use post-fabrication IC testing, both of which are unsatisfactory or unsound. As a sound alternative, this project designs and fabricates verifiable hardware: ICs that provide proofs of their correctness for every input-output computation they perform in the field. These proofs must be efficiently verifiable in less time and energy than it takes to re-execute the computation itself.

Building upon exciting recent theoretical and practical advances in verifiable outsourced computation for the cloud, this project develops new techniques that exploit the unique constraints and adversary models that relate to the verifiable hardware problem. In addition, the project also develops new practical approaches to the problem of general verifiable computation. As a broader impact, computing systems security is one of the greatest technological problems faced by society today. Verifiable hardware is an essential foundation for building future computing systems that are reliable and free from catastrophic security failures. The ultimate goal of this project is to make verifiable hardware practical and accessible for use in cryptographic and mission-critical hardware applications through open-source tools. The PIs are strongly committed to education and public outreach by producing widely-used course materials and taking active roles in outreach at minority-serving universities, community colleges, student organizations and high schools.

por.por_cntn:
The semiconductor supply chain is globally distributed and complex. Chips are frequently manufactured at offshore untrusted semiconductor foundries, raising the possibility of subtle but intentional and malicious modifications of a chip design, for instance, inserting backdoors and kill-switches that would cause the chip to misbehave once operated.

This project sought to use advances in cryptography to secure chips against such modifications. Specifically, over the years, cryptographers have constructed so-called verifiable computing (VC) protocols that allow a party (say an individual name Alice) to outsource computations to another individual, say Bob, who is untrusted but be convinced that Bob has performed those computations correctly. To do so, Bob provides to Alice an easily checkable "proof" that the computation was correctly performed. If Bob's computation is incorrect, the proof will not check out and Alice can throw away the computation. Beyond this, other cryptographic protocols are also useful for this problem: for example, privacy-preserving computing protocols allow Alice to outsource computations to Bob on secret inputs that Bob can never see. Zero knowledge proofs allow Bob to convince Alice of a statement that depends on a secret that only Bob has, without ever revealing the statement to Alice. With these in hand, the project sought to build the first ever class of chips that prove the correctness of their own computations using the aforementioned cryptographic protocols, while also innovating on the crypto side and developing new protocols. 

Our proposed research has made several key contributions. As promised, we have demonstrated the first ever hardware implementations of chips secured against malicious modifications using VC. We have injected bugs and Trojans in these chips, prototyped on special circuits referred to as field-programmable gate arrays (FPGAs), and demonstrated that these can be caught by verifying the proofs returned by the chip. Our examplar chip performs matric multiplications, a key computation performed extensively in modern deep neural networks. Therefore, our methods can be of huge value to modern artificial intelligence (AI) applications that are increasingly being implemented on custom hardware.

A second innovation has been the design of specialized cryptographic protocols for deep neural networks.  We have shown new VC protocols for deep networks that are orders of magnitude faster than more general VC protocols. Conversely, we have also shown that modern deep neural networks are ill-suited for cryptography: operations that are simple to perform in plaintext (without crypto) take orders-of-magnitude more time to compute cryptographically. As such, we have designed new types of deep neural networks optimized for cryptography, including for VC and for privacy-preserving computations.

A third key contribution are new cryptographic protocols and methods, including new VC and ZKP methods. These new VC and ZKP protocols seek to make it easier and faster to generate proofs and to verify them. Further research has devised parallelization strategies to dramatically speed up proof verification. Put together, the project has succesfully transformed the idea of chips that prove their own correctness from concept to practice, while innovating new cryptography protocols and applications whose value goes well beyond the hardware setting.

Numerous PhD students have been graduated, including several women PhD students. Our research had been disseminated at leading cybersecurity, cryptography and AI conferences and journals, and discussed with several industry partners.

Modified by: Siddharth Garg
